subsection.title: Norm and dot product
subsection.p: We'll begin with algebraic properties of norm and dot product.

statement.p:
The following are true for all vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} in \R^n and all scalars k.
\unorm{v} \ge 0, and \unorm{v} = 0 only for \uvec{v} = 0.
\norm{-\uvec{v}} = \unorm{v}.
\norm{k\uvec{v}} = \abs{k}\unorm{v}.
\norm{\uvec{v}-\uvec{u}} = \norm{\uvec{u}-\uvec{v}}.

warning.p: The norm is not additive; that is, it is not true in general that \norm{\uvec{u}+\uvec{v}} is equal to \unorm{u}+\unorm{v}. Sometimes the two quantities are equal, as you are asked to consider below, but the best we can say about the norm of a sum is contained in below.

proposition.title: Algebra rules of the dot product

statement.p:
The following are true for all vectors \uvec{u}, \uvec{v}, and \uvec{w} in \R^n, and all scalars k.
\udotprod{v}{u} = \udotprod{u}{v}.
\dotprod{\uvec{u}}{(\uvec{v}+\uvec{w})} = \udotprod{u}{v} + \udotprod{u}{w}.
\dotprod{\uvec{u}}{(\uvec{v}-\uvec{w})} = \udotprod{u}{v} - \udotprod{u}{w}.
\dotprod{(\uvec{u}+\uvec{v})}{\uvec{w}} = \udotprod{u}{w} + \udotprod{v}{w}.
\dotprod{(\uvec{u}-\uvec{v})}{\uvec{w}} = \udotprod{u}{w} - \udotprod{v}{w}.
\dotprod{(k\uvec{u})}{\uvec{v}} = k(\udotprod{u}{v}).
\dotprod{\uvec{u}}{(k\uvec{v})} = k(\udotprod{u}{v}).
\udotprod{v}{v} = \unorm{v}^2.
Both \dotprod{\uvec{v}}{\zerovec} = 0 and \dotprod{\zerovec}{\uvec{v}} = 0.

subsection.title: Vector geometry inequalities and uniqueness of vector angles

paragraphs.title: The Cauchy-Schwarz inequality
paragraphs.p: Here we will state the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality in its usual form. Note that this version applies to every pair of vectors, even if one is (or both are) the zero vector.

statement.p: For every pair of vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} in \R^n, we have \abs{\udotprod{u}{v}} \le \unorm{u}\unorm{v}.

proof.p: Because \udotprod{u}{v} could be negative, we will change our last inequality above to \abs{\udotprod{u}{v}}^2 \le (\unorm{u}\unorm{v})^2.

aside.title: Note
aside.p: Squaring turns negative into positive anyway, so it doesn't matter if we introduce absolute value brackets to do that first.

proof.p: In words, this inequality says that the square of one number is less than or equal to the square of another number. But when we square two numbers, the bigger number will always result in the bigger square (as long as neither number is negative). Since neither \abs{\udotprod{u}{v}} nor \unorm{u}\unorm{v} can be negative, the bigger number must be \unorm{u}\unorm{v} to result in a bigger square (or the two numbers could be equal). That is, \abs{\udotprod{u}{v}} \le \unorm{u}\unorm{v}.

statement.p: For every pair of nonzero vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} in \R^n, there is one unique angle value \theta in the domain 0 \le \theta \le \pi so that \cos\theta = \frac{\udotprod{u}{v}}{\unorm{u}\unorm{v}}.

paragraphs.title: The triangle inequality
paragraphs.p: Here is another commonly used inequality. Remembering our view of sums of vectors as a chain of changes in position, it basically says that the shortest path between two points in \R^n is the direct path.

statement.p: For every pair of vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} in \R^n, we have \norm{\uvec{u}+\uvec{v}} \le \unorm{u} + \unorm{v}.

aside.title: Check your understanding
aside.p: Can you think of a situation where \norm{\uvec{u}+\uvec{v}} and \unorm{u} + \unorm{v} are exactly equal? Is this the only way this would happen?
